data.title: Homotopia 2015: Nine must-see shows
data.meta_description: The annual LGBT festival is promising a celebration of life and art
data.text:
The annual LGBT festival is promising a celebration of life and art

Liverpool’s Homotopia festival – the annual celebration of lesbian, gay, bisexual and transgender culture – is back for a 12th year, and taking over city venues from a month from this Friday.

This year’s festival has the theme Art = Life, and features more than 50 events from dance, debate and literature to visual art, film and comedy.

‌

Festival favourites like David Hoyle and Polari are joined by Homotopia newcomers, while this year the programme also expands to St Helens, where there’s an exciting project afoot with Heart of Glass.

Homotopia artistic director Gary Everett says of the festival theme: “If silence equals death as it did at the start of the AIDS crisis then we believe art equals life.

“Art is a joyous expression of all that makes us human and for lesbians, gays and Trans people who continue to be marginalised, criminalised and persecuted around the world, art is often their only means of self-expression.”

‌

Here are nine must-see events taking place as part of Homotopia.

Alien Sex Club – Camp & Furnace

October 30-November 29

Alien Sex Club is major multimedia project by British artist John Walter, exploring the relationship between visual culture and HIV today.

‌

The exhibition features a large-scale installation comprising sculpture, painting, video, performance and installation.

Visitors are immersed in a multisensory world in which they can watch videos and live performances, get lost in a cruise maze and have a drink in the performance bar.

Using hospitality, fortune-telling, comedy and the aesthetic of carnivals and festivals Alien Sex Club introduces issues to a wide audience and aims to make the subject palatable, interesting and fun.

‌

It will also involve artists, activists and HIV specialists, clinical academics and scientists in collaborations for a public programme of talks and performances.

Fenella Fielding/The Bride of Frankenstein - Liverpool Small Cinema

October 31

Homotopia doesn’t usually ‘do’ Halloween. But this year it’s making an exception. with a spooky night screening of The Bride of Frankenstein, starring Boris Karloff, and added entertainment including, duck apples, pumpkins, fangs and bats.

‌

Guest of honour at the event at Liverpool Small Cinema in Victoria Street is the vampirish Valeria from Carry On Screaming herself, Fenella Fielding, who returns to the festival after an appearance last year.

She will also take part in the official festival opening event on Thursday evening.

Scratch and See - Unity Theatre

November 3

‌

See excerpts from three new works created by Keddy Sutton (Freddy & Friday), Ashleigh Owen (The Rise and Fall of the Hamburger Queen) and Jamal Gerald – FADoubleGOT.

Liverpool actress Keddy’s Freddy & Frida is set in a time before Eurovision when “a famine of cheesiness swept the land”.

But somewhere in the far reaches of Switzerland a small contest of nations began, a contest known as The Eurovision Song Contest.

‌

The Gods of Cheese saw that it was good and decided to form a super-group from their only begotten children, Freddy and Frida.

Their eternal mission is to spread the Euro-pop message to every man, woman and child; Peace, Love and Cheesiness.

Ecco Homo - Unity Theatre

November 5-7

‌

Performer and LIPA tutor Nick Phillips, aka Naughty Nickers, returns to Homotopia with Ecce Homo.

The intimate cabaret show, being staged at the Hope Place theatre over three nights, has touches of 30s Berlin, music hall and Broadway.

Naughty Nickers dishes up tales of his time with the legendary Bloolips, his 34-year romance with Dr Jeffrey, and how he left his heart and much more in San Francisco.

‌

His personal recollections become not only a love story but a testament to the social history of the gay movement from the late 1970s to the present day.

Panic Lab - Unity Theatre

November 10-11

This Homotopia premiere is produced by physical theatre company Panic Lab and created and performed by Joseph Mercier and Jordan Lennie, with text by a Canadian playwright, filmmaker and theatre director Jordan Tannahill.

‌

Theseus Beefcake explores masculinity, competition and pain thresholds.

See Mercier and Lennie test their friendship and themselves, with wrestling and mixed martial arts thrown in!

The show journeys in to the “dark labyrinth” of masculinity, martial arts, death metal, American frat culture and Greek mythology.

‌

Jean Abreu Dance, Blood - Unity Theatre

November 12

Brazilian choreographer and performer Jean Abreu explores the interior workings of his body in Blood, a piece originally commissioned by the Royal Opera House.

It was inspired by artists Gilbert & George and features projections from their series The Fundamental Pictures, magnified and animated by digital artists Mirko Arcese and Luca Biada.

‌

Blood, billed as a captivating multisensory experience, is a celebration of the strange beauty of life.

Meanwhile the accompanying music comes from Paul Wolinski of glitch rock band 65daysofstatic.

Sarah Waters in Conversation - Unity Theatre

November 13

‌

Tipping the Velvet and The Night Watch author Sarah Waters will take part in the festival, discussing her latest book The Paying Guests at this ‘in conversation’ event in the intimate surroundings of the Unity theatre.

The novel is both a psychological thriller and the story of a doomed love affair, set in the transitional social world of 1920s London.

Its 49-year-old author, who was born in Wales, was shortlisted for the Baileys Women’s Prize for Fiction earlier this year.

‌

Ed Firth, 21 Centuries - Liverpool city wide

November 15-December 1

The London portrait artist, who has exhibited extensively across the UK and is known for his paintings of men with beards, plans to take over up to 21 outdoor sites across the city to create his street art exhibition during the festival.

Each of the paintings, which will eventually wash away with the weather, will be inspired by a cultural memory from each century over the past 2,000 years.

‌

The works are hand-drawn, finished digitally, printed, cut and fixed to walls as wheatpastes.

Panti Bliss - Epstein Theatre

November 21

Ireland’s “national treasure, performance giant and accidental activist” Panti Bliss is set to appear in one of the most highly-anticipated events of this year’s festival.

‌

Panti, the alter ego of County Mayo performer Rory O’Neill, found herself in the middle of a media storm christened ‘Pantigate’ in 2014.

She became a YouTube sensation when a speech she made about homophobia went viral, was broadcast around the world, debated in parliament and even remixed by the Pet Shop Boys – sparking a conversation about equality and feeding into Ireland’s recent Marriage Equality referendum success.

High Heels in Low Places, at the Epstein in Hanover Street, is her riotous stand-up show about life after ‘Pantigate’.

‌
